item.title: Need help with icons in JButtons
item.dc:creator: @pizza_pie pizza pie
item.description:
@pizza_pie wrote:

† Nirvana †:

I’ve done both its just not working.

Omg, who remembers when I had the exact same problem. Alright, well if you use paint to make your images, you might as well as jump off a cliff or just dl Painter25.exe It has the feature of transperancy but is hard to use.

So, I make my pics in paint, cut and paste it into Painter25 and save it as a gif. If you need transperency, than you can just go to options > GIF image > transperency. Alright, well try that and if that doesnt work you can try option two that i stated above.

item.title: Need help with icons in JButtons
item.dc:creator: @imafatmess imafatmess
item.description:
@imafatmess wrote:

Iamadam:

lets you very easily specify an image file (jpeg or GIFs)

Picture.ico is not a jpeg or a gif!!! Anyway, surely this could easily be found on google in a matter of seconds…

10-20 seconds of searching found this site:

http://www.apl.jhu.edu/~hall/java/Swing-Tutorial/Swing-Tutorial-JButton.html

On the site it shows an example of an icon being added to a JButton:

[quote=“JButton Tutorial Website”][code]import java.awt.;
import javax.swing.;

public class JButtons extends JFrame {
public static void main(String[] args) {
new JButtons();
}

public JButtons() {
super(“Using JButton”);
WindowUtilities.setNativeLookAndFeel();
addWindowListener(new ExitListener());
Container content = getContentPane();
content.setBackground(Color.white);
content.setLayout(new FlowLayout());
JButton button1 = new JButton(“Java”);
content.add(button1);
ImageIcon cup = new ImageIcon(“images/cup.gif”);
JButton button2 = new JButton(cup);
content.add(button2);
JButton button3 = new JButton(“Java”, cup);
content.add(button3);
JButton button4 = new JButton(“Java”, cup);
button4.setHorizontalTextPosition(SwingConstants.LEFT);
content.add(button4);
pack();
setVisible(true);
}
}[/code][/quote]

Now, wasn’t that hard!

I suppose, though, if you still don’t understand that, you could have a quick lil’ look in the java api at the JButton class. You can see from there that there is a JButton constructor with one parameter being icon… Slowly you’d begin to hear cogs whirling in your head then suddenly you’d spring to life and shout: “leik 0mfgz0rz! t1z a 1C0n Th1ngY 1n thes c0nztruct0rszzzeZZZzzzZz!!!1!11!!1”. Here is what it says (incase you can’t be bothered to look:

JButton

public JButton(String text,
Icon icon)

Creates a button with initial text and an [i][b][u]icon[/u][/b][/i].

[b]Parameters:[/b]
    text - the text of the button
    icon - the Icon image to display on the button

If you didn’t know what this icon object actually was, just click on the Icon link and you can see for yourself!!! How exciting!!"""!¬!!!¬!

Read full topic
item.source: Need help with icons in JButtons

then give it a value…

Then it doesnt appear on my button…

Any yes my ‘button2’ has been declared… (public static JButton button2;)

[14:22] zero: help meh please? http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,186364.0.html
Icon img = new ImageIcon("icon.ico"); // Get the icon
JButton button = new JButton("A button with an icon", img); // Declare a new JButton with text and the icon
add(button); // add it to the frame

item.source: Need help with icons in JButtons

item.title: Need help with icons in JButtons
item.dc:creator: @Iamadam Iamadam
item.description:
@Iamadam wrote:

Swing has a utility class called ImageIcon that lets you very easily specify an image file (jpeg or GIFs). The simplest way to associate an image with a JButton is to pass the ImageIcon to the constructor, either in place of the text or in addition to it.

ImageIcon someImage = new ImageIcon(imageFileName); JButton j = new JButton(someImage);

Read full topic
item.source: Need help with icons in JButtons
